Seduction of Miss Emma Martin, a “sister;” bastardy; kept evangelizing very successfully, until presented with an heir; confessed, expelled.
Adultery, seduction of Rosa Arnold, aged 15; elopement with her, deserting wife and three children, penniless; embezzlement of $400, church funds: expelled.
Slander from pulpit; sued by Bronson.
Indecent exposure of person; church trial, expelled.
Adultery, seduction of “sister” Sarah Sherman; elopement with her.
Beattie, Rev. T. R. or F. R.
Immoral assault; slandering Miss Sershman; arrested; bail $4,000; sued for $10,000, slander.
Drunkenness, lying; got gloriously drunk, denied it; expelled.
Assault and battery on a “brother;” lying, swindling, making debts everywhere, never paying; fled.
Lying, slander, so says Rev. Blanchard.
Murder of John Turner; stabbed him three times.
Adultery, seduction, elopement with wife of Rix, deserting wife and children; temperance lecturer.
Fighting with one of his elders; got whipped; elder’s name, Robert Hood.
Deserting wife, leaving her penniless and sick in bed; investigated; resigned.
Literary piracy; preached Wilberforce’s sermons; quack doctor; sued for malpractice; deposed.
Gross swindling U. S. pension agent; robbed a blind and helpless soldier of $7,278, pension; swindled a widow out of $2,535.
Rape, adultery, on 13-year-old daughter of Mr. Anderson; arrested; prison at Leavenworth.
Murder of W. J. Hunnicritt; confessed; hanged.
Larceny, deserting wife, drunkenness, gross fraud, lying, cheating.
Assault and battery; knocked Capt. McCaulley down and pounded him.
Denton, Rev. J. L. or J. W.
Deserting wife and children; proposing marriage to several ladies; arrested.
Robbery of his friend and room-mate; drunkenness; fled; spent the cash; his friend died; confessed.
Swindling in connection with “Isabella mine;” editor Christian Advocate, resigned.
Seduction, bastardy, with “sister” Jennie Williams; prosecuted.
Lying, so says Rev. Dr. Mackie.
Assault with intent to murder his wife and family, with poison and “cold steel;” arrested; prison.
Indecent proposals to Miss Lizzie Jordan; slandered her and her family from the pulpit; sued by her brother Charley Jordan.
Slander of P. Hackman; fined $3,400; selling liquor in his church and school; fled to Canada.
Rape upon his young housekeeper; she complained to Bishop Spaulding.
Immoral assault on two girls, one 12, other 14; fled.
Illicit distilling; two stills destroyed by U.S. officials; fled.
Adultery, seduction, and elopement with Mrs. John E. Rose; arrested, fined $400, jailed at St. John’s, N. B.
Eastman, Rev. Chas. A., Geo. E. Hindley, C. B. Merrill.

Adultery, bigamy, lying, false personation, deserting wife and family; first married Miss Emma Keyes, of Lewiston, Me.; second marriage with a Miss Piper, of Alamo; broke jail at Kalamazoo; sent to Michigan penitentiary; very religious.
Assault and battery; beat Deacon Johnson over the head with a chair for saying “Good-morning.”
Fern, Rev. Thomas, or Fernly, Rev. Thos. A.
Libel on William Entriken; arrested; most popular preacher in the city.
Libel upon Rev. T. B. Conway; sued for $40,000; fighting.
Drunkenness, visiting house of ill-fame; riot, arrested, jailed, confessed, fined.
Assault and battery on a little girl; tore some pictures away from her; she went into convulsions; sued for damages by her father; fined; riot with 1,000 Irish against the father.
Burglary, immoral assault; shot, badly wounded, while scaling back wall of yard at midnight, by Roger Pearson.
Slander; sued by E. Cowlee, of the Leader.
Larceny, stealing books; fighting at church trial with Rev. Wallace and others.

Seduction, bastardy, with Mary Proctor, née Ryan; confessed, subsequently denied; after her marriage adultery and bastardy with her again; first child named John Patrick Gleason, second Richard Gleason Ryan; suspended from priesthood by Bishop Kenrick.
Seduction, elopement with a 13-year-old daughter of a “brother.”
Swindling Mrs. Simpson, while dying, out of her property; sued.
Adultery, seduction of Miss Maria Delly; took her to conference with him; slept with her at hotel.
Larceny of cattle and hogs, notorious thief; prison.
Insulted Mrs. Foster; demanded her removal from hotel table because she was an actress.
Adultery, seduction, with wife of Mr. Hoff; writing her to leave her husband and live with him; detected, fled, deserting wife and children.
Medical quack; ruined lady’s nose; sued.
Breach of promise; engaged to three ladies; fled to escape tar and feathers.
Immoral assault on “sister” Maggie Kinney; bounced with a black eye by Mike Dunphey.
Slandering Leon Lanson and Mathilde St. Jean; sued.
Defrauding dying man out of $90,600; gross swindling; compelled by courts to disgorge.
Slandering his hired girl, because she told of his swearing, “God damn it!”
Drunkenness, lying, false personation; claimed to be a French count; quarreling for the pulpit.
Larceny, stole $310 from Neil Smith; fled.
Adultery; drunkenness in a brothel at St. Louis; arrested.
Adultery, seduction, elopement with a “sister,” deserting wife and children; arrested by his own son; forgery of recommendation.
Adultery, drunkenness, beating wife, profanity, lying, assault to murder; arrested, prison.
Adultery, seduction, elopement with wife of John S. Brayman, leaving her children; Johnson is single, and a great revivalist.
Gross swindling of widow and orphan children: arrested.
Robbing mails a long time; prison.
Seduction, bastardy, breach of promise; arrested; seduced Miss Lizzie Miller; she supported him while studying theology; he married another; expelled; confessed on trial.
Adultery, seduction of wife of “Brother” Hinkle; confessed; said he “couldn’t help it;” married.
Drunkenness, breach of promise, left the church; promised to marry “Sister” Angela; took her to hotel, staid with her several days, then deserted her, and returned to priesthood.
Assault and battery; arrested; fighting for pulpit.

Swindling Catholic church at Greenpoint out of church property to amount of about $200,000; threatens excommunication
if they “kick;” obstructing legal process; defying the law.
Quarreling, threatening to fight in church.
Adultery both in Kentucky and Pennsylvania; marries a wife but retains an old “flame” as mistress; forgery of letters of recommendation; lying; church trial.
Lying and libel, so says Dr. Deems.
Inhuman cruelty to wife; arrested, bailed; adultery, fled.
Adultery, seduction of a “sister,” wife of R. E. Booth; married, large family; editor Baptist Messenger.
McGill, Rev., alias M. F. Devlin.
Drunkenness oft repeated; fined often; often in workhouse; sent up for sixty days, and $25 fine.
Disturbing school; drove teachers and scholars out of doors, and would not let them return; brutal assault on women and children.
Inhuman cruelty to wife and children; divorced by court.
Adultery, fornication, visiting house of ill-fame in Louisville; drunkenness, assault and battery; arrested, fined; lying about it.
Miller, Rev. T. B.; also Major, Rev. Major

“Miller” as dean, and “Major” as secretary of the medical college; gross swindling, gross fraud; allowed a paper reporter to register as a student, and then for $25 gave him a diploma as M.D.; Miller expelled, Major suspended.
Lewd and lascivious conduct; convicted; fraudulent divorce.
Suicide, leaped from steamer St. Paul.
“Immoral character;” dismissed; sodomy and unnamed crime with young “brothers” of his flock, too vile to print.
Adultery, seduction of Mrs. Robert Hawks; caught by her husband locked in her bedroom at night, at 273 Thirty-first street, New York; she the mother of several children; arrested.
Seduction, adultery with Mary Rogers, deserting wife; illegal divorce; beating wife, lying, perjury, drunkenness, and delirium tremens; threatening to kill Bishop Kerwood and wife.
Slander of Mrs. Green; Mr. Green killed him.
Indecent exposure of person to a lot of little girls, pupils under his care; immoral assault on Miss Ida Scott; failing in this, slandered her.
Assault and battery upon parishioner; pounded Sunday law into him.
Immoral assault on many ladies and young “sisters;” expelled ignominiously.
Prayed for the death of two men at church; one died next day.
Adultery, seduction, bastardy, with Cora Wheeler.
Swindling, obtaining money under false pretense.
Adultery, seduction, elopement with Miss Kate Ashton, daughter of a wealthy “brother,” deserting wife and children.
Incest, adultery, seduction, elopement with wife’s niece, writing to his wife not to expect him back; deserting wife and children.
Larceny in Germany; drummed out as rebel surgeon; counterfeiting, state prison; literary piracy, stole Ingersoll’s temperance speech.
Rockwell, Rev. J. B.; or Rev. J. H. Harvey.
Gross swindling, illegal use of mails; arrested, prison.
Married Miss Gessner; forgery, signed a man’s name to note who could not write; discovered, fled, arrested.
Gross swindling, made great debts and ran away; immorality.

Drunkenness; expelled at Athens from Baptist church; went to Michigan, became a Congregational preacher, expelled; goes to Oakwood, finally to Lapeer, where he changes to Baptist again; pastor at Pontiac, again expelled, but continues to preach; popular preacher.
Adultery with Indian women; carried off and supposed murdered by them; he was missionary among the Crows.
Adultery with “Sister” Wells, wife of Rev. M. F. Wells, who is blind; caught by a neighbor; church trial.
Adultery, seduction of “sister,” wife of A. L. Halwick; she told; Sullivan married.
Lewd woman; arrested in house of ill-fame; was a captain in Salvation Army.
Assault with intent to murder the organist John Richards; arrested; Richards died of the injuries; slander from pulpit; sued by Daniels for $10,000; judgment against him.
Slander from pulpit of Dr. Desgrobois; sued; compromised, paying $1,000.
Sherin, Rev. A., alias A. Sheridan, or A. Sherdin, or A. Sherdian.

Adultery, seduction, false personation; occupied same room at Dakota House, Huron, with Miss Rice; registered as “A. Sheridan and wife;” introduced her as “Miss Rice, my wife’s niece;” preached next day at Flandran, “Miss Rice, a cousin,” still with him; married, and family: confessed registering “A. Sheridan and wife,” and occupying same room, “merely to protect from harm a modest, timid, warm-hearted woman, of generous impulses.”
Immoral assault, went into Miss Clark’s bedroom twice and tried to seduce her, while his wife was sick; sued.
Borrowed $1,128 for election expenses; wouldn’t pay, sued.
Outrageous conduct, expelled; fled to escape tar and feathers; adultery, seduction, bastardy, with wife’s sister, aged 16; confessed.
Brutal assault on a woman, sent to workhouse.
Drunkenness, beating wife very often; church trial.
Rape on a little five-year-old girl; caught in the act, and arrested.
Arson; burnt, with help of some “sisters,” two churches; arrested, prison.
Begging while getting $1,400 a year; lying generally.
Criminal carelessness—or worse; killed his wife accidentally(?) with a revolver.
Beating wife; arrested, prison; robbing his wife of money.
Unnamed crime with boys under his charge at Brotherhood College; caught in act, expelled, fled, arrested, prison; a most beastly wretch; he was principal of the college.

Immoral assault on Widow Marsh; slander and libel; read a paper before college trustees, alleging that she tried to seduce him, and was a bad woman with others; lying; expelled; perjury on slander trial; a most infamous scoundrel; convicted by a jury.
Slander, lying; so says Rev. Blanchard, president of the “parson factory.”
Immoral assault on Miss Graham; church trial; lying.
Adultery, seduction, incest, with Lena Capron, his twenty-year-old niece; deserting wife and three children; beating wife; paramour confessed; he was arrested; he “exposed Spiritualism.”
Rape on girl 11 years old, he 70; arrested, jailed.
Drunkenness oft repeated; church trial, suspended.
Grossly swindling a brother preacher, Rev. John McComber, of Minnesota; gross fraud, sued.
Wharton, Rev. J. G., or J. W. Wharton, alias J. D. Hill.

Adultery, seduction, elopement with organist, wife of J. R. McGill; forgery for $2,600; deserting wife and 15 children; stole $2,600 from his wife; Mrs. McGill deserting three children; embezzlement; arrested, indicted.
Fighting in pulpit with Rev. Green, threatening to kill him.
Rape on Hattie Carr, aged 7 years, a pupil; arrested, state prison five years; principal of St. Joseph’s College; formerly; principal of De la Salle (Catholic) Institute, New York.
Drunkenness for a week, gambling in a saloon.
Egotism, puffing himself in the papers.
Rape on Mrs. S. F. Gibbs, by means of opiates; sued.
Adultery, inhuman cruelty to wife; lying, charged by wife in divorce suit.
Kissing Mrs. Grimsley; shot by Mr. Grimsley, resigned.

Because Wilson family deferred one year marriage of their daughter to him, drove nail through foot of their horse, necessitating killing, put petroleum in their well, terrorized them with forged warnings to leave, put powder in Wilson’s forge; escaped.
Murder (see under Peters, Rev. J. H.)
Theft and forgery; sentenced to five years’ imprisonment.
Charged with accepting bribes and embezzling.
Sporting tendencies; engaged to two women at once.
Cursing his neighbor and praying the Lord to destroy him; this in a disorderly manner and at open window; fined $10.
Charged with immorality; lying; maladministration; profanity.
In North Carolina, assault with intent to commit rape; at Winchester, going to St. Louis on a spree and attempting to shoot woman in a disorderly house.
Charged with theft of horse and sleigh.
Charged with bastardy. (Was fond of abusing Roscoe Conkling and other Freethinkers for Infidelity and immorality.)
Swindling by alleged cures; starving and freezing his children; fled on suspicion of having murdered his boy.
Writing letter to mulattress to assign immoral meeting; expelled.
Breach of promise (engaged to five girls at once).
Charged by church committee with lying and wholesale love-making.
Charged with continuous drunkenness which caused him to disappoint several audiences for lectures.
Charged with adultery and suborning witnesses.

Cruelty to wife, forcing her to black his boots before church and rewarding her with an insult; she became insane, recovered, got divorce; embezzlement
at Cameron, Mo.
Threatening life; slander; convicted and suspended.

Made improper visits to Mr. Grace’s wife; on Grace’s charging criminality eleven parishioners dragged him to the priest’s house amid cries of “Lynch him!” when the priest beat him in the face, the party forced him to his knees, and he retracted to save his life; Grace sues for $15,000.
Theft of watch and $2 from preacher; imprisoned one year.
Seduction; abuse and desertion of the seduced girl after marriage.
Elopement with a married woman, deserting wife and children.
Charged with drunkenness and disorderly conduct.
Forgery of pension affidavits for purpose of sale.
Assault on a parishioner during services.
Charged with immorality with women; fled, deserting family.
Beating and choking a lady; fined $50.
Eloped with young parishioner, taking all wife’s money and jewelry.
Charged with selling vote and influence; asked to resign.
Seduction, and abettal of an abortion which proved fatal.
Charged with seduction of his stepdaughter, which resulted in her death.
While married, writing love-letters to girls; expelled.
Threatening with revolver new claimant of pulpit, from which Hembree had been deposed for disreputable conduct; arrested.
Assault and battery of a woman; fined $700 and imprisoned ninety days.
Charged with immorality with a young lady; forced to resign.
Cruelty to wife at Kingston; elopement at Mott Haven.
Extensive swindling; arrested for attempt to poison a lady whom he had married for her money.
Unprovoked murder of a man whom he had failed to intimidate from marrying a lady loved by both.
Desertion of wife and children for another woman.
Attempt to elope and leave family.
Charged on twenty-three counts with indecent conduct with young ladies.
Threatening life of rival evangelist; held in bonds to keep peace.
Charged with wife-desertion, drunkenness, and lying.
Charged with rape of eleven-year-old girl.
Seduction of girls; fled to escape lynching.
Desertion of wife and twelve children to elope with mother-in-law.
Sodomy with boys; seduction of little girls; dismissed; confessed.
Swindling congregation; shot dead by them.
Indecent liberties with eight-year-old girl; sentenced to penitentiary.
Writing love letters to several ladies with whom he had no acquaintance.
Charged with obtaining money under false pretenses; arrested.
Charged with immodest conduct with young ladies; forced to resign.
Charged with bigamy, and using obscene language.
Compelled dying man to will him his estate.
Elopement with married woman, deserting wife and four children.

Seduction of and elopement with the wife of the
famous politician McDonald, who says: “She became a fanatic in religion, and the brute brought a tremendous religious influence to bear on her. Under his powerful leverage, the church, he made her an easy prey. To think that he lived on me, blessed my food, took my children on his knee and blessed them!”
Assault and terrible cruelty to wife; divorce given her.
Arrested for seduction and many immoralities with women.
Breach of promise (engaged to three girls); fled.
Theft of Bible and other property.
Seduction under promise of marriage, and desertion.
Allowing child to die without medical service.
Charged with whipping his servant-girl for her spiritual discipline.
Drunkenness; forgery; consorting with lewd women; embezzling church money.
Insulting ladies who would not attend his meeting; mobbed out of the neighborhood; convicted.
Criminal intercourse with girl under fourteen.
Ran up board bill until landlady became embarrassed for money; suggested that he pawn her watch for her, and did so and absconded with the proceeds.

With Father Andrews governed a convent of boys; one escaped and revealed that the two priests had killed a student, telling the escaped one that priests had a right to murder; Andrews, with the justice of peace who held inquest, and, being a strong Catholic and under the priest’s control, returned verdict of suicide, arrested; Peters missing.
Drunkenness and embezzlement of church funds; deposed.
Indecent liberties with little girls; under assumed character of John Smith sentenced to ninety days in workhouse, whereupon revealed true profession and was but fined $100.
Elopement with another man’s wife, deserting his own.
Assaults on girls between twelve and fifteen with intent to rape.
Theft of a theological work and other books.
Charged with theft; fined for fighting in church.
Struck lady in face with prayer-book and used indecent language to her, because she refused share of assessment demanded; deposed.
Killed wife, son, and self because wife would not support him.
Cruelty to wife; expelled; wife got divorce.
Sending to wife of a parishioner, with whom he maintained a liaison, a love-letter such that he was arrested for mailing obscene matter.

Elopement with fourteen-year-old girl, deserting
family.
Charged with indecent conduct with young ladies, and proposing adultery to married.
Charged with deliberately planning the cruelties that forced his wife to get divorce, so he could marry another woman.
Improper relations with a parishioner’s wife.
Immorality; deposed; threatened to kill church officers; arrested for carrying concealed weapons.
Drunkenness; using lewd language to women; desertion of wife and children.
Twice running away with woman for a short time; finally absconding with one altogether and leaving wife in want.
Non-support of wife; divorce granted her; arrested for intoxication.
Charged with indecent conduct to married lady; her husband and others dragged him from the pulpit and stopped his preaching.
Conducting lottery at church fair; arrested.
Charged with swindling in the sum of $1,000 by a clergyman of Newton Lower Falls, Mass.
Borrowed $350 and left, leaving note that he should commit suicide.
Charged with hugging and kissing one of his female teachers after she had retired for the night.
Forgery; libel; embezzlement; opening others’ letters; false entries.
Swindling; engaged to many girls at once; fled.
Improper liberties with women; gambling; drunkenness; expelled.
Elopement with Mrs. Henry; taking with him missionary funds; leaving wife and five children destitute; she leaving husband and two children.
Charged with desertion of wife for Mrs. McIntyre, upon the latter’s receiving $6,000 insurance money.
Indecent liberties with little girls at parochial school; fled from tar and feathers.
Desertion of wife for other women.
Desertion of wife; liaison with prostitute; return and redesertion of wife for same prostitute.
Desertion of wife and children; evangelizing accompanied by another woman as pretended wife.
Swindles aggregating several thousand dollars; his conference in a warning circular describes him as “a good preacher—can talk and cry a man into believing him a saint.”
Forgery; two murders; threefold bigamy; theft; arrested in pulpit at close of sermon.
Arrested on charge of burning church to get insurance.
Immodest conduct with a young lady; forced to resign.
Grand larceny—renting a furnished house and selling the furniture; was found in Buffalo living with a mulatto girl.
Indecent language and letters; suspended one year.
Thefts and improper conduct with girl.
Elopement, leaving wife and seven children.
Elopement with Mrs. Covert, she taking considerable of her husband’s money.
Seduction and murder by poison of Susie Beck.
Criminal connection; fled, deserting wife and family.
Charged with coercing a weak-minded woman into giving $20,000 to an institution of his.
According to charges, persuaded wife to live apart from him, and used this absence as ground for divorce; obtained bishop’s consent to remarry by saying ground was adultery.

According to charges paid improper attention to Mrs. Bell; kicked wife out of bed because she would not receive Mrs. Bell; threatened to put her in jail; made her kneel and swear to obey him in all things as the Bible commands, and consent to his courting Mrs. Bell; arrested.
Adultery with W. Dyer’s wife; murder of Dyer.
Arrested on charge of rape of a thirteen-year-old girl.
Desertion of family; immoralities with female parishioners in Canada.
Drunkenness; violent assault on a butcher.
Felonious assault on wife of elder. Accused; arrested.
Violation of postal law; called brother minister names on a card. Fined.
Malversation of funds; left town with camp-meeting gate receipts. Accused.
Horse stealing; confessed; 4 years in penitentiary.
Drunkenness; arrested for disturbing the peace.
Abortion, charged with attempting to procure. Arrested.
Immorality, with disorderly woman; suspended by church.
Desertion; also accused of bigamy and perjury.
Grand larceny; pleaded guilty; to penitentiary.
Slander; sued for $10,000 by Pres. Long, Antioch College.
Accused of breaking up home of William Hay.
Lying; fraudulent dealings; immoral conduct. Expelled from church.

Robbery of co-operative store. In jail awaiting trial; made saws of his wife’s corset steels. Escaped with five other prisoners. Says jailer: “He was the most religious man I ever saw. He prayed night and day.”
Wrote insulting note to a lady; drunkard, opium eater, threatened the life of another minister. Whipped by citizens and run out of town.
Improper proposal to Mrs. Samuel Cole. She knocked him down twice and swore out warrant for his arrest Church revoked his license.
Illicit relations with several members of the church. Confessed, in substance, in meeting.
Adultery; eloped with a married woman. Carried away others’ funds.
Deception; concealed his marriage when at Chillicothe, Mo., and made love to girls. Suspended by the church.
Adultery; eloped with organist, aged 17. Left wife and five children.
Slanderous talk about women; whipped in the pulpit.
Burglary; arrested at St. Joseph, Mo. Confessed.
Embezzlement, while treasurer of the state insane asylum. Indicted, arrested, confessed.
Receiving money under false pretenses. Had an independent income from copyright on illus. edition of Lord’s Prayer and Ten Commandments. 3 yrs in pen.
Defaulter, as ass’t postmaster. Arrested, confessed.
Improper conduct; accused; tarred and feathered.
Immorality and misappropriation of funds. Found guilty.
Rape; 20 years and 3 months. Attempted abortion, also. While at Crookston was suspended from church for alleged improper relations with married woman.
Horse stealing; accused; arrested. A traveling evangelist and said to be mixed up in other crookedness.
Murder, the victim having made charges reflecting on Cox’s daughter.
Vulgarity and obscenity in pulpit. Accused.
De Castries, L’Abbe de la Croix.
Smuggling; accused; arrested; prosecuting attorney failed to act. Jumped bail.
Forgery and immorality. Lived a double life. Accused. Arrested.
Cruelty, to inmates of Orphans’ Home. Heavily fined.
Violent assault on a young man. Fined.
Violation of law for protection of song birds. Fined.
Rape and bastardy. Accused; indicted; arrested.
Forgery, embezzlement, wife desertion, adultery. Accused, arrested.
Adultery with 14 year old girl. Accused; arrested.
Malversation of funds and false statement of account. Promised to make good the loss, and presbytery censured him.
Criminal assault Accused, indicted. Brought counter actions for slander.
“Contracting debts without intention to pay.” Intoxication. Accused; left town.
Embezzlement, perjury, forgery, theft. Accused, arrested.
Adultery; eloped with wife of another minister. Sold his father’s horse and buggy, after borrowing them.
Assault and battery; went into neighbor’s house to break up dance; fined; refused to pay; jailed.
Obtaining money under false pretenses; arrested; suspended from ministry.
Criminal libel growing out of newspaper controversy; indicted.
Attempted immorality; at 70 tried to make appointments with young girls. Suspended. Once at Van Wert, O., cowhided for slandering women of congregation.
All-round swindler. 9 years, from Jackson, Tenn., to Columbus, O., for fraud.
Forgery and obtaining money under false pretenses. Accused, arrested.
Swindling; 9 years and 6 months in Sing Sing.

Murder of minister who had supplanted him; shot him as he was preaching. Penitentiary for life; escaped 5 years later arrested at East Birmingham, Ala., where he had preached for 3 years as W. W. Thompson.
Deserted wife; made false charges to get divorce.
Unfaithfulness and desertion. Was sued for divorce, which was granted by default.
Theft; stealing silver candlesticks from Cath. churches; accused, arrested.
Fraud; arrested. Victimized Christians in many places.
Adultery; eloped to Canada, arrested, pleaded guilty.
Larceny; sentenced to jail, but sentence changed to fine that he might preach at camp meeting.
Immorality and dishonesty. Accused, deposed by bishop, arrested.
Bastardy; accused, expelled from presidency of North-western Baptist College.
Immorality, visited low resorts for 5 years. 75 years old. Dismissal recommended.
Malversation of funds; accused, held for grand jury.
Immorality; in the evening awarded medals at Catholic colored school, and spent the night in debauch with colored women; next day drunk on street.
Pension frauds in Pennsylvania and Maryland. Arrested.
Seduction and adultery; many times; arrested.
Cruelty to prisoners, farmed out to him by government.
Criminal libel of his presiding elder; convicted.
Immorality; consorted with the frail; superiors imposed 2 years penance.
Attempted assault on a little girl. Accused, arrested. Also drunkenness.
Murder of Mary Gilmartin; attempted suicide, confessed.
False representations; suspended from ministry. Had before tried to take child from his wife; fined.
Forgery and pension fraud; for 18 years drew pension in name of widow of former slave; woman had been dead 15 years. 18 months’ imprisonment.
Larceny as bailee of money belonging to insurance companies of which he was agent. Accused, arrested.
Unlawful conduct; failed to report marriage of W. C. P. Breckinridge in time prescribed by law; fined.
Assault with pistol and dirk on a member of his congregation in a dispute over infant baptism. Then went to his church and preached eloquent sermon.
Adultery; eloped. Accused. Wife took him back.
Bigamy. Accused, arrested. Admitted, but thought he had conclusive evidence of first wife’s death.
Falsification, intemperance, intent to defraud, embezzlement, immorality, etc., all charged by his assistant, Rev. J. W. Putnam.
Assault with intent to kill his wife. Arrested. Tried twice to commit suicide.
Libel, growing out of the Potter-Putnam quarrel (see Potter, Rev. D. C.). Indicted.
Adultery; eloped with his organist Arrested in B. C.
Drunkenness; visiting house of ill-fame. Expelled from ministry by unanimous vote of conference.
Cruel and inhuman treatment of his wife. She sued for divorce.
Systematic defrauding of government as superintendent. Accused by General Armstrong. Fled.
Assault and battery. Fined and imprisoned; judge told him evidence would have convicted him of the more serious charge of attempted criminal assault.
Incest with his daughters. Expelled from ministry; indicted; arrested.
Abused wife and children. Accused; resigned pastorate.
“Sensational and highly improper conduct with several ladies.” So accused by his wife in suit for divorce.
Attempted rape of little girl. Arrested; held to await action of grand jury.
Adultery. Accused; expelled from membership in ministerial association after he started the “Amer. Patriot.”
Petit larceny; passing checks on banks in which he had no funds. Arrested.
Violation of postal law; sent cards dunning another minister and accusations against him to the minister and the sessions. Pleaded guilty and fined.
Adultery and lying. Charges sustained by church and fellowship withdrawn, 116 to 59.
Extreme cruelty to child, a boy of seven. Fined $500 with alternative of 6 months in jail, the full penalty.
Rape of 16 year old girl; by threats kept her silent for months until concealment was no longer possible. Arrested; jailed.
Larceny of cow. In jail in default of bail.
Lying, improper conduct, adultery; charges sustained by presbytery. Suspended from the church.
Improper propositions to a woman. Held guilty by council and ordination papers surrendered.
Extreme cruelty, wife beating; alleged in divorce proceedings by wife.
Adultery; attempt to seduce a young woman whom he had just baptised. Expelled from church.
Terrible cruelty to his wife. When wife was dying.
Bastardy. Charge brought by his divorced wife, at whose hotel he stopped after divorce was allowed. F’d guilty.
Forgery, of name of a minister to an order for goods. Arrested.
Adultery; eloped; had crusaded bitterly against amusements.
Seduction of girl of 16. Forced to marry her; expelled from church.
Rape of 13-year-old daughter of one of his parishioners.
Assault of girl of 16; accused; arrested.
Bigamy. Expelled from church and ministry.
Misappropriation of funds of Law and Order League of which he was president.
Criminal libel. Arrested on complaint of young woman parishioner.
Cruelty, and adultery with lewd women, alleged by wife in suit for divorce.
Jailed for spending on himself money collected for sick soldiers.
Plucking live chickens. Sent to jail.
Abused his wife so she got a divorce; liar, fomenter of discord, slanderous, obscene, said the ecclesiastical court that deposed him.
Expelled from ministry for alleged immorality.
Improper conduct, cruelty to wife; deposed.
Charged with improper conduct toward girl of nine years.
Adultery; gave up his position as minister.
Expelled from church for immoral conduct.
Charged with murder of his wife. Her body found in pond near their house. A short time before she ran to a neighbor’s, saying Bailey had attacked her with a knife.
Attempting to imitate the Holy Ghost, husband ejected him and mob gave him coat of tar and feathers. Was a faith-cure miracle-worker, and was stopping in house of a believer.
Improper conduct. Eloped with young woman to Detroit, where they lived a while.
Immorality. Wife sues for a divorce; says she picked him out of the gutter when he was a gambler and boozer.
Charged with theft of goods from a department store; goods found on his person.
Assault, on another minister, in religious quarrel.
Bank-wrecker; was convicted; was president and cashier of bank.
Alcoholism, said doctors at Bellevue hospital.
Defalcation; was county school commissioner; short $5,000; suspended from office; fled.
“Drank too much” on a trip to Niles; suspended from ministry.
Adultery, perjury, slander, lying. Long church trial later, confessed, and dropped from ministry.
Charged with rape of girl of fourteen; arrested in church; admitted to bail; disappeared during trial.
Sending obscene matter through the mails; jailed.
Murder. Shot his wife and then himself.
Charged with embezzlement as administrator of an estate; compromise, friends paying $1,300, the amount of alleged defalcation.
Accused of indecent assault on 10-year-old girl. Arrested.
Fornication; sent one girl away when about to become a mother; ran away with another.
Grand larceny; to penitentiary; has record for forgery, blackmail, horse theft, intimidation, bigamy, assault, obtaining money under false pretenses, and robbery of a child.
Rape and seduction; absconded when grand jury indicted him.
Arrested for forgery; said also to have two wives.
Gross immorality, slander, and profanity; church committee recommended expulsion from church.
Adultery; left wife and eloped with a widow.
Improper relations, with two young women.
Unnatural crime; fled to escape tar and feathers.
Conduct unbecoming a clergyman; dropped from ministry; wrote love letters and kissed the sisters.
Extreme cruelty; so wife alleged in divorce suit.
Illegal voting; arrested on charge of.
Disorderly conduct; arrested in New York.

Charged with seduction of colored servant, acquitted by his church although his attorney had paid the girl $200. She died under abortion. At Leavenworth Embree was fined for shooting a valuable bird dog.
Gross immorality confessed; expelled from ministry and church.
Untruthfulness and deceit; asked to resign or stand charges.
Immoral conduct; left Waco under those charges.
Wanted for extortion and swindling. Under conviction for burning a schoolhouse in Charlotte.
Assault on 16 year old girl. Convicted; 7 years.
Interference, causing divorce proceedings and his whipping by the husband.
Robbery; missing goods from department store found in his house.
Misappropriating property of his church; arrested.
Relations with woman not his wife; wife secured divorce.
Assault and battery; arrested at Old Orchard, Me., on that charge.
Cruel and inhuman treatment, and drunkenness; alleged in wife’s suit for divorce.
Charged with forcibly detaining a woman; arrested; jumped bail; rearrested.
Illicit relations with servant girl of weak mind; expelled from the ministry.
Attempted rape of girl of eighteen; arrested.
Drunkenness. Resigned to escape court martial.
Indicted by grand jury for stealing hog from convict farm.
“Chased by a mob for making an insulting proposition to a respectable girl on the street.”
Malversation of funds entrusted by a widow for two infants; in reply, said most was used for masses for souls of woman and her husband.
Fraud, immorality in speech and behavior, drunkenness, and profanity; said the presbytery.
Attempting crim. assault; sued by young woman.
Bastardy; girl of sixteen asks him to acknowledge paternity of child.
Charged with criminal neglect of girl when in delicate condition. Arrested.
Charged with murder of two girls; remains in furnace of church; he disappears; warrant issued.
Charged with slander by another minister; arrested.
Counterfeiting outfit found in his cellar; arrested.
Improper hypnotic influence over servant girl.
Choked his wife; jailed in default of paying fine.
Eloped with neighbor’s wife. Nearly lynched. Also charged with arson. Committed suicide.
Bastardy; charged by woman soldier of Army.
Adultery, as charged by wife in suit for divorce.
Improper behavior; arrested on charge of fifteen-year-old girl.
Arrested, charged with killing ten-months’-old babe of his housekeeper.
Stealing; accused. Wife also accuses him of immoral conduct.
Slander; said from pulpit two-thirds of girls of Fresno were ruined before they were fourteen; rescued from mob; left town.
Assault and battery of servant girl.
Left wife and children; eloped with 16-year-old girl; purs’d by girl’s father (Rev. J. Widsby); shot dead.
Eloped with young girl, leaving wife with child.
Indecent language in pulpit, keeping a mistress; removed.
Dealing in green goods, passing counterfeit money; arrested.
Charged by the deacons with immorality.
Charged with attempt to defraud creditor; arrested.
Improper relations with parishioner’s wife. Dismissed from pulpit.
Breach of promise of marriage; convicted; he was 80; she an aged spinster.
Accused of seduction and bastardy; put on trial.
Charged by grand jury with sending improper matter through the mails.
Stole watch from his host, a bishop in his church.
Disorderly conduct at Sal. Army meeting. Fined.
Accused of alienating affections of wife of minister.
Arrested on charge of attempting to pass forged note.
Sued by young woman for $1,500, alleged to have been obtained from her under false pretenses when she was supposed to be dying.
Contempt of court. Fined and jailed.
Violation of law requiring report of marriages.
Stealing books from counters of stores.
Eloped with married woman; brought back; begged pardon.
Undue intimacy, says brother minister in suit for divorce.
Brutal treatment of wife; divorce granted to her.
Murder; killed his wife by poison.
Attempted assault on wife of his host.
Eloped with young woman, leaving wife and grown up daughters; also charged with grand larceny.
Eloped with married woman, leaving wife and children.
Forgery; long criminal career. Alias Rev. Mark Thompson and Rev. Edward C. Aiken.
Defamation, unministerial, unchristian conduct. Expelled from ministry.
Alienation of affections; whipped by husband.
Charged with adultery by wife in suit for divorce; also with lying, dishonesty, intemperance.
Adultery, as charged in divorce suit of parishioner.
Slander of actress, Jane May. Sued, retracted, settled with her lawyers.
Outrageous assault on farmer’s wife; confessed.
Slander; sued by Rev. Mr. Widdemar; mulcted.
“Acting in a manner not consistent with good morals.” Suspended from ministry.
Turning out his wife and taking in another woman; tarred and feathered.
Left family and eloped with young girl.
Pounded wife on head with brass-bound Bible; wife paid his fine; got drunk on communion wine and beat her again; that landed him in jail.
Arrested on charge of illicit manufacture of cigars.
Arrested on charge of committing unnatural crime.
Cruelly beat and kicked 15-year-old daughter; accused; in defense said she used profane language.
Seduction of girl of 15; eloped, leaving family.
Forcible entry of house and threatening occupants with firearms; arrested.
Cruelty and neglect charged by wife in divorce suit.
Accused of malicious trespass by his presbytery.
Tried to break into room of female evangelist.
Charged with breach of promise of marriage.
Quarrelling; knock-down row with Bapt. minister.
Eloped with married woman, as charged.
Undue familiarity with married woman; chased by angry husband; fled; dismissed from church.
Improper actions toward little girls; left town.
Seduction, assault, abduction. Indicted by grand jury. Married the girl, so escaping trial.
Theft; accused; goods found in his house.
Manslaughter; killed baby in shooting at rowdies who were hooting him as he preached.
Attempted seduction; whipped by husband; conf’d.
Robbery of post office. Accused and arrested.
Assault upon girl of eight years; sentenced for nine years and six months.
Improper behavior on street; accused; arrested.
Unnatural practices; turned out of the pulpit.
Adultery; took his organist to Pittsburg, where they registered as man and wife; on their way home she jumped from the steamer and drowned.
Robbery; opened another’s registered letter; accused; arrested.
Horse-stealing. When his first term expired six deputies from three states with six warrants were waiting for him.
Immoral character; dropped by the presbytery.
Disorderly conduct, in pointing pistol at two men; “was excited,” he said, and was let off.
Bastardy; accused. Ecclesiastical court finds him guilty of immorality.
Cruelty to his children; adultery; accused and threatened with tar and feathers.

div1.head: CRIMES OF PREACHERS—PART II.
div1.p:
(Each paragraph below gives in their order the date of the offense, the name of the preacher, his residence and denomination, and the character of the crime charged.)
1906. Abbott, Rev. E. J., Stony Point, N. Y. Presbyterian. Though married, made love to postmistress.
1901. Abbott, Rev. John F., Henryville, Ky. Methodist. Adultery.
1906. Abel, Rev. A. C., Chicago. Methodist. Bigamy.
1899. Abernethy, Rev. Wm., Circleville, O. Assignation; adultery; arrested; fined.
1901. Adams, Rev. C. G., Berkeley, Cal. Episcopal. Murder.
1909. Adams, Rev. C. G., St. Louis, Mo. Episcopal. Bigamy.
1907. Adams, Rev. H. A., New York. Episcopal. Left wife to elope with young girl.
1911. Adams, Rev. Henry T., Arcata, Cal. Protestant Episcopal. Arrested for larceny, and confessed.
1913. Adams, Rev. N. Q., Starkville, Miss. Baptist. Indicted as bank director for receiving deposits after the bank was declared insolvent.
1912. Adkins, Rev. G. W., Poteau, Okla. Baptist. Convicted of grave robbery.
1902. Alden, Rev. Chas. A., New York. Grand larceny. Indicted.
1907. Alexander, Rev. Mr., Indianapolis, Ind. Arrested for shooting craps.
1914. Alexander, Rev. Mr., Chicago, Ill. Murderous assault.
1907. Alexander, Rev. D. R., Bluefield, W. Va. Stabbed saloonkeeper.
1913. Alexander, Rev. Henry B., La Crosse, Wis. Obtaining money under false pretenses. Sent to the state penitentiary for one year.
Ali, Rev. Joseph, Newark, N. J. Catholic. Assaulting 9-year-old girl.
1909. Allan, Rev. A., Cleveland. Drunkenness; arrested and fined.
1905. Allen, Rev. Frank, Guthrie, Okla. Revivalist. Disturbing the peace. Fined $5. which he refused to pay, and went to jail.
1903. Allen, F. T., exhorter, Santa Paula, Cal. Methodist. Assaulting little girls.
1903. Allen, Rev. George, Morrisville, Pa. Stealing. Ten years at hard labor.
1899. Allen, Rev. George, Poughkeepsie, N. Y. Presbyterian. Engaged to two women; tried suicide.
1906. Allen, Rev. G. E., Breckinridge, Ky. Found in compromising position with wife of host.
1900. Allen, Rev. Henry E., West Derry, N. H. Methodist. Betrayal of 16-year-old girl.
1910. Allen, Rev. Jesse, Nowata, Okla. Co-respondent in divorce.
Allen, Rev. Willard S., Boston, Mass. Methodist. Stealing $80,000 from preachers’ fund.
1899. Allen, Rev. W. A., Asbury Park, N. J. Methodist. Deserting wife; cruelty; divorced.
1901. Allen, Rev. Mr., Uniontown. Hanged for outrage and murder.
1912. Alley, Rev. G. W., Royal Center, Ind. Methodist. Adultery; pleaded guilty and paid fine.
1908. Allison, Rev. Charles E., Yonkers, N. Y. Presbyterian. Suicide.
1901. Ament, Rev. Mr., Missionary in China. Blackmailing Chinese. Arrested.
1907. Amhyrst, Rev. H. G., Lafayette, Ind. Dishonesty; embezzlement; falsifying. Suspended.
1907. Amis, Rev. W. T., Hot Springs, Ark. Baptist. Contempt of court.
1901. Ammons, Rev. W. J., Georgia. Breaking into post-office. Convicted.
1900. Anderson, Rev. G. W., Frederick Co., Va. Deserting bride; mobbed out of town.
1912. Anderson, Rev. James, Paterson, N. J. Baptist. Defaulted on note given to a widow to secure loan.
1901. Anderson, Rev. Jos. (alias Geo. Hayford), Phoenix, Arizona, and California. Evangelist. Bank swindles.
1912. Anderson, Rev. J. S., Houston, Tex. Baptist. Suspected of complicity in the wholesale murder of Negroes.
1911. Anderson, Ralph D., Lincoln City, Del. Divinity student. Stole horses.
1906. Anderson, Rev. T. C., Tarentum, Pa. Presbyterian. Beating and choking his wife.
1911. Andrews, Charles, Portland, Ore. Street preacher. Arrested for disorderly conduct, not specified.
1907. Andrews, Rev. J., Monroe City, Mo. Baptist. Left wife to join circus; dealt faro bank; married snake charmer.
1902. Andrews, Rev. J. R., Lansing, Mich. Baptist. Delinquency in money matters; arrested; went insane.
1903. Andrews, Rev. M. C., Oshkosh, Wis. Episcopal. Consorting with immoral women. Whitewashed.
1914. Anthony, Rev. George W., New York, N. Y. Episcopal. Conspiracy.
Aquila, Rev. E. D., Mount Carmel, Pa. Catholic. Arrested in New York for speeding.
1900. Archer, Rev. J. W., Norfolk, Va. Baptist. Illegal voting; arrested.
1902. Ardman, Rev. John, Scranton, Pa. Catholic. Approved assassination of President McKinley; enjoined by bishop.
1904. Armer, Rev. Norman, Sacramento, Ky. Presbyterian. Murder of son; 21 years’ imprisonment.
1907. Arnold, Rev. J. H., Ga. Evangelist. Cruelty to son. Six months in chain gang.
1904. Arthur, Rev. A. A., Hiawatha, Kan. Evangelist. All-round fraud; forged check for $10,000 in Texas; confessed; many aliases.
1898. Arthur, Rev. Chas. M., Weston, Conn. Congregational. Found guilty by conference of obscenity, violent actions, cruelty to wife; divorced.
1907. Arthur, Rev. C. W., Syracuse, N. Y. Congregational. Grand larceny.
1908. Arthur, Rev. Mark, Spalding, Idaho. Presbyterian. Criminal libel.
1899. Ashton, Rev. Mr., Union City, Mich. Baptist. Criminal neglect of wife in child-bed.
1908. Assenicio, Rev. Mr., New York. Catholic. Attempted suicide.
1901. Astwood, Rev. H. C. C., Brooklyn, N. Y. Methodist. Unministerial conduct; arrested for fraud; suspended.
1908. Atherton, Rev. Albert, St. Louis, Mo. “Household Faithful.” Taking indecent liberties.
1909. Atherton, Rev. D. F., Haverhill, Mass. Co-respondent in divorce case.
1909. Atkins, Rev. P. J., Ogdensburg, N. Y. Methodist. Suicide.
1913. Atkinson, Rev. Edward J., Lima, O. Baptist. Abandonment and non-support of 5-year-old daughter.
1908. Atkinson, Rev. J. C., Atlanta, Ga. Methodist. Sued for slander.
1900. Attaway, Rev. A. M., Columbus, S. C. Attacked his wife and died of heart disease while attempting to throttle her.
1913. Atwood, Rev. W. C., Brookfield, Mo. Presbyterian. Assault.
1906. Austin, Rev. J. W., Gainesville, Ga. Methodist.
Eloped with married woman whom he had “saved” at a revival.
1899. Axtell, Rev. J. J., Royal Oak, Mich. Prize fighting; non-support of wife; divorce.
1905. Ayres, Rev. Early, Lee Co., Tex. Cattle stealing; arrested in Berwyn, I. T., while preaching.
Axtel, Rev. P. D., Pittsburgh, Pa. Presbyterian. Suicide.
1912. Ayres, Rev. William B., Wollaston, Mass. Congregational. Sued for alienation of affections by an irate husband in his parish.
1907. Babcock, Rev. C. A. C., Frankfort, Ind. Campbellite. Illegal marriage; immoral conduct.
1901. Babcock, Rev. Maltbie D., New York, N. Y. Presbyterian. Suicide.
1913. Backtell, Harry S., Pittsburgh, Pa. Noted “boy evangelist” and highly accredited “soul-saver.” Swindling by means of worthless checks.
1909. Bailey, Rev. Geo., Cincinnati. Abused his family.
1905. Bailey, Rev. J. J., Fletcher, Okla. Fighting.
1906. Bain, Rev. E. S., Waterloo, N. Y. Baptist. Arson.
1913. Baird, Rev. E. J., Woodland, Cal. Episcopal. Inhuman and abusive treatment of wife.
1912. Baird, Rev. L. W., Winsted, Conn. Lay preacher. Arrested for embezzlement.
1900. Baker, Rev. Mr., Cleveland, O. Discovered in a girl’s room in a compromising position.
1904. Baker, Rev. C. S., Wilmington, Del. Methodist. Gambling; suspended.
1914. Baker, Rev. Francis C., New York. Congregational. Grand larceny.
1899. Baker, Rev. Jos. S., Minneapolis, Minn. Evangelist. Wife beating; convicted; ten days.
1904. Baker, Rev. Seward, Geneseo, Ill. Unitarian. Drunkenness; long spree; dismissed.
1914. Baker, Rev. William L., New York, N. Y. Violation of the medical law.
1904. Baldwin, Rev. Mr., Warsaw, Ind. Dunker. Assault and battery; arrested.
1903. Baldwin, Rev. Ralph H., New York, N. Y. Marrying two wives and deserting both.
1907. Balea, Rev. Moise, Cleveland. Greek. Criminal libel.
1907. Ballard, Rev. M., Texarkana, Ark. Murdered neighbor. Shot by officers whom he resisted.
1906. Banbury, Rev. James, Brooklyn, N. Y. Congregational. Left wife to elope with choir singer.
1900. Bandy, Rev. S. S., Arkansas City, Ark. Baptist. Assault on 14-year-old girl.
1905. Bane, Rev. A. H., Hollow Rock, Tenn. Baptist. Unlicensed liquor selling; prosecuted.
1902. Barbee, Rev. Wm., Cookville, Tenn. Evangelist. Bigamy; five years’ imprisonment.
1907. Bard, Rev. Paul, Detroit, Mich. Methodist. Took saloonkeeper’s wife.
1902. Barfell, Rev. Othias, Columbus, O. United Brethren. Suicide by hanging.
1914. Barker, Rev. C. A., Benhams, Va. Methodist Episcopal. Lewdness; convicted and fined.
1900. Barnard, Rev. E. H., Sylmar, Pa. Incest and child murder; arrested.
1899. Barnett, Rev. Mr., Cambria, O. Methodist. Familiarity with female member of flock; attacked marshal with knife; arrested.
1902. Barnhart, Rev. C. W., Tylers Switch, N. Y. Evangelist. Horse stealing; fled from warrant.
1907. Barnwell, Rev. G. L., Atlanta, Ga. Baptist. Kissed married woman.
1914. Barr, Rev. Earl, Macedonia, O. Christian. Immoral conduct.
1900. Barr, Rev. L. W., Fairmont, W. Va. Presbyterian. Forgeries and embezzlements; absconded.
1911. Barrakman, Rev. Mr., Waterloo, Ill. Divinity student. Arrested for robbery.
1911. Barranger, Rev. N. H., North Yakima, Wash. Christian. Sued for $25,000 damages for stealing affections of another man’s wife.
1909. Barret, Rev. J. W., Cleveland, O. Obtaining a signature under false pretenses; 18 months.
1902. Barrett, Rev. Mr., Brazil, Ind. Evangelist. Slandering women; fled from tar and feathers.
1910. Barrett, Rev. Wm. I., Blairville, Pa. Presbyterian. Arrested for criminal libel.
1909. Bartemes, Rev. Mr., Amherst, O. Before grand jury for slander.
1899. Barth, Rev. Benj., Paterson, N. J. Christian. Absconding debtor; household goods attached.
1907. Bartle, Rev. S. D., Mechanicsville, Ia. Methodist. Suspended for intimacy with telephone girl.
1900. Bass, Rev. L. D., Saltsburg, Pa. Baptist. Fraudulent mail business.
1899. Bateman, Rev. C. C. Army chaplain. Insubordination and violation of articles of war; dismissed.
1901. Baum, Rev. H. M., New York. Bankrupt, he concealed assets with intent to deceive.
1911. Baxter, Rev. C. L., Council Bluffs, Ia. Methodist. Sued for breach of contract.
1911. Baxter, Rev. John F., Brooklyn, N. Y. Catholic.
Charged with using questionable methods in collecting money for benefit of a church in Ireland.
1911. Baylis, Rev. Edgar E., Somerville, Mass. Sentenced to three months in jail for libel.
1907. Baynes, Rev. H. L., Englewood, Ill. Left wife to elope with girl.
1900. Beahm, Rev. J. C, Brentsville, S. C. Betraying 18-year-old girl; penitentiary for five years.
1912. Beall, Rev. J. W. H., Hampden, Md. Assault and contempt of court.
1905. Beavers, Rev. Geo. S., Gainesville, Tex. Incest with daughter; arrested.
1899. Beceljak, Rev. John, Cleveland, O. Catholic. Vagrancy; arrested.
1902. Beebe, Rev. Mr., Delaware, O. Horse stealing; arrested.
1913. Beeler, Rev. Orville, Plainsville, Ind. Larceny.
1912. Beers, Rev. W. L., Wakarusa, Kans. Methodist. Wife-murder.
1913. Beesley, Rev. Jesse, St. Louis, Mo. Baptist. Bigamy.
1899. Belding, Rev. J. M., Lapeer, Mich. Presbyterian. Indecent advances to boys. Admitted his guilt. Suspended.
1902. Bell, Rev. Basil, Huntington, Pa. Murderous assault.
1902. Bell, Rev. Edwin, New Canaan, Conn. Baptist. Slander. Arrested.
1907. Bell, Rev. E. A., Chicago. Fighting.
1913. Bell, Rev. J. M., McKinney, Tex. Campbellite. Adultery and wife desertion.
1912. Bennett, Rev. C. O., Millwood, Ga. Baptist. Killed in duel with his cousin.
1913. Bennett, Rev. Fred E., Evanston, Ill. Attempting to bribe a witness to commit perjury.
1902. Bennett, Rev. Jos., Lansford, Pa. Owed church $200; disappeared, leaving letter for girl with whom he was accused of intimacy, saying he had committed suicide.
1909. Bennett, Rev. Jos., Owensboro, Ky. Suicide.
1907. Bentz, Rev. John, Covington, Ky. Sued for slander.
1912. Bergen, Rev. John, New York, N. Y. Roman Catholic. Indecent attempt on young girl; convicted; later gave name as Rev. John P. Devaney.
1902. Berkemeier, Rev. H. J., Poughkeepsie, N. Y. Lutheran. Summoned to court for detaining immigrant girl.
1899. Berrien, Rev. J. C, Steubenville, O. Crime of a revolting nature with boys.
Berry, Rev. Chas. L., Pawnee, Okla. Presbyterian. Looting bank; twenty years’ sentence.
1907. Bertrand, Rev. August, Windsor, Mich. Attempted to entice 12-year-old girls.
1911. Besse, Rev. Henry T., San Jose, Cal. Sued for breach of promise.
1905. Bettes, Rev. Sam’l G., Parkersburg, W. Va. Evangelist. Bastardy; arrested as he was about to sail for Panama as chaplain appointed by President Roosevelt.
1900. Bettles, Rev. Albert, Lincoln, Neb. Evangelist. Poisoning himself and girl he had betrayed.
1905. Betts, Rev. S. E., Topeka, Kan. Methodist. Slander of another minister’s wife.
1911. Bichel, Rev. Albert A., Baltimore, Md. Methodist. Deserted family.
1911. Bichel, Carl, Kansas City. Divinity student. Held for murder.
Bigam, Rev. R. J., Milledgeville, Ga. Methodist. Immorality and drunkenness.
1910. Biggs, Rev. George W., Cincinnati, O. Former chaplain of Texas Legislature. Arrested as a common thief; confessed.
1908. Billings, Rev. C. M., Blackville, S. C. Baptist. Intimate with Negro girl, servant of family. Resigned; left town.
1910. Bivans, Rev. J. T., Salina, Kan. Methodist. Immoral conduct; suspended.
1901. Bivens, Rev. R. D., Nicholasville, Ky. Methodist. Assault; pleaded guilty; fined.
1901. Bixby, Rev. Jos. P., Boston, Mass. Contempt of court.
1901. Black, Rev. Henry, chaplain British cruiser at St. Johns, N. F. Suicide.
1901. Blackiston, Rev. W. E., Windsor, N. J. “Left a trail of scandal behind him,” says his wife.
1902. Blake, Rev. John H., Montclair, N. J. Methodist. “Serious charge” by a woman; arrested.
1904. Blakemore, Rev. F. P., Tecumseh, Neb. Methodist. Immorality and profanity.
1912. Blanchet, Rev. John B., Philadelphia, Pa. Episcopal. Charged with stealing church and contents by means of a fraudulent deed. Also arrested for cruelty to animals.
1910. Bliesz, Rev. A., Dayton, O. Catholic. Living in illegal state with woman.
1899. Bliss, Rev. Leon D., Great Barrington, Mass. Congregational. Defendant in $5,000 damage suit for slandering women.
1906. Bloom, Rev. A. W., San Jose, Cal. Christian. Eighteen months for horse stealing on plea of guilty.
1909. Bockman, Rev. H., Beaver Dam, Wis. Lutheran. “Peeping Tom.” Ousted.
1904. Bolton, Rev. Floyd, Six Mile, Ind. Deceiving young women; fled.
1899. Boone, Rev. Daniel, Washington, Md. Stealing from woman; disorderly; fined.
1910. Boord, Rev. Thomas G., Pittsburgh, Pa. Baptist. Tried to sell his children at auction.
1911. Booth, Rev. A. L., Elizabeth City, N. C. Methodist. Misappropriated missionary and conference funds.
1905. Booze, Rev. Coleman, Buchanan, Va. Baptist. Set fire to his church and smashed doors of residence with an ax; arrested.
1905. Bope, Rev. F. W., Zanesville, O. Episcopal. Debauchery and licentiousness.
1901. Born, Rev. Peter, Detroit, Mich. Lutheran. Abusing wife and adultery.
Borrough, Rev. Geo. T., Brooklyn, N. Y. Episcopal. Passing forged check; grafter.
1906. Boscher, Rev. Henry, New York. Lutheran. Vagrancy and fraud.
1908. Bostwick, Rev. Mr., Wyaconda, Mo. Methodist. Criminal assault.
1912. Bourne, Rev. Alexander P., Cambridge, Mass. Constructive larceny.
1911. Bowen, Rev. Franklin, Paterson, N. J. Guilty of disorderly conduct.
Bowers, Rev. E. T., Kansas City, Mo. Presbyterian. Criminal intimacy and gross immoralities; found guilty.
1909. Boyd, Rev. F., Logan, O. United Brethren. Assault; six years.
1899. Boyer, Rev. C. H., D. D., Kansas City, Kan. Evangelist. Horse stealing; five years in Missouri penitentiary.

div1.head: The Devil Fishing.

lg.l: The Devil sat by the river’s side—
The stream of time, where you’ll always find him—
Casting his line in the rushing tide,
And landing the fish on the bank behind him.
He sat at ease in a cozy nook,
And was filling his basket very fast;
While you might have seen that his deadly hook
Was differently baited for every cast.
He caught ’em as fast as a man could count;
Little or big, it was all the same.
One bait was a cheque for a round amount;
An assemblyman nabbed it, and out he came.
He took a gem that as Saturn shone;
It sank in the water without a sound,
And caught a woman who long was known
As the best and purest for miles around.
Sometimes he would laugh and sometimes sing,
For better luck no one could wish,
And he seemed to know to a dead sure thing,
The bait best suited to every fish.
Quoth Satan: “The fishing is rare and fine.”
And he took a drink, somewhat enthused:
And yet a parson swam round the line,
That e’en the most tempting bait refused.
He tried with his gold and his flashing gems,
Hung fame and fortune upon the line,
Dressing gowns with embroidered hems,
But still the dominie made no sign.
A woman’s garter went on the hook;
“I have him at last,” quoth the devil, brightening;
Then Satan’s sides with laughter shook,—
And he landed the preacher as quick as lightning!
